metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of forest structure parameter survey at the temporary forest sampling plot in the Dayekou watershed foci experimental area (2008)
metadata.description:
The forest hydrology experimental area of Heihe River integrated remote sensing experiment includes the dense observation area of Dayekou basin and the dense observation area of Pailugou basin. Due to the concentrated distribution of the fixed sample plots in the drainage ditch basin, these sample plots lack of representativeness to the forest of the whole dayokou basin, so in June 2008, 43 temporary forest sample plots were set up in the whole dayokou basin. The data set is the ground observation data of the 43 temporary plots. In addition to the measurement and recording of stand status and site factors, Lai was also observed. 
The instruments used to measure each wood in the sample plot are mainly tape, DBH, flower pole, tree measuring instrument and compass. The DBH, tree height, height under branch, crown width in cross slope direction, crown width along slope direction and single tree growth were measured for each tree. WGS84 latitude and longitude coordinates of the center point of the sample plot were measured with different hand-held GPS, and the positioning error was about 5-30m. Other observation factors include: Forest Farm, slope direction, slope position, slope, soil thickness, canopy density, etc. The implementation time of these temporary sample plots is from 2 to 30 June 2008. 
The data set can provide ground data for the development of remote sensing inversion algorithm of forest structure parameters.

Quantification.Question: How many temporary forest plots were surveyed in the Heihe comprehensive remote sensing joint experiment in 2008?

Definition.Question: What does '样地每木检测测量' mean in the context of forest hydrology experiments?
Definition.Answer: '样地每木检测测量' refers to the process of measuring and recording the state of each tree within a sample plot in forest hydrology experiments. It involves using instruments like tape measures, diameter tapes, and clinometers to measure attributes such as diameter at breast height, tree height, branch height, crown width in cross-slope and slope directions, and individual tree growth conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying reasons that lead to positioning errors when using handheld GPS devices for forest plot data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Positioning errors when using handheld GPS devices for data collection in forest plots can be attributed to various factors, including the quality of the GPS device, the presence of dense forest canopy which obstructs satellite signals, and environmental conditions such as terrain and weather. In the context of the data collection mentioned, the use of different handheld GPS devices resulted in positioning errors ranging from 5 to 30 meters, indicating variability in accuracy due to these factors.

Causal Consequence.Question: What could be the potential outcomes on forest hydrology research if temporary forest plots are utilized for data collection across an entire watershed rather than relying solely on fixed plot locations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing temporary forest plots across an entire watershed allows for a more comprehensive representation of the forest, addressing limitations posed by fixed plots that may lack representativeness. This approach can enhance the accuracy of forest structure parameter remote sensing algorithms by providing ground-truth data that reflect a wider diversity of forest conditions. It also offers a broader understanding of how forest hydrology varies within different areas of the watershed, potentially improving water management and conservation strategies.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and procedures can be employed to accurately measure tree metrics like diameter at breast height, tree height, and crown width in complex forest environments?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments such as measuring tapes, diameter tapes, ranging poles, clinometers, and compasses can be used for measuring tree metrics. The procedure involves conducting every-tree measurements, including diameter at breast height, tree height, crown width across different directions, and assessing individual tree growth conditions. Additionally, handheld GPS devices are used to determine the central point coordinates with a positional error of 5-30 meters.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the accurate measurement of tree growth characteristics and forest structure in the field of forest hydrology?
Enablement.Answer: Data collection techniques for measuring tree growth characteristics and forest structure include using instruments such as measuring tapes, diameter tapes, range poles, tree calipers, and compasses. Measurements taken include breast height diameter, tree height, crown width in cross-slope and slope directions, and individual tree growth status. Additionally, handheld GPS devices are used to measure the WGS84 coordinates of plot centers, with a positioning error of around 5-30 meters. Other plot observation factors include the associated forest farm, slope direction, slope position, slope degree, soil thickness, and canopy closure.
